intro: Psychotria dorotheae subsp. dorotheae, commonly known as the "Coca of the Andes," is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a flowering plant belonging to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species. The plant typically grows as an erect shrub with lance-shaped leaves and produces small, clustered flowers. Its most notable botanical feature is the presence of alkaloids, particularly cocaine, in its leaves. This subspecies is distinguished by its morphological characteristics and chemical composition, making it a significant subject in both botanical and pharmacological studies.
